Description: Egyptian terracotta mould fragment. An upper part broken from the front mould for a man, standing with his arms to his sides: he is lost from the waist down. He has a bald head, wrinkled forehead, heavy eyebrows and thickened lips, the lower one rather twisted as well as a broken nose. His ears are set high. Although he does not wear a topknot, he seems to be a boxer, as what are probably the upper thongs of a sphaira or caestus (a boxing-glove) appear on the impression’s left arm; the right arm also has a tiny area that may be part of such a thong. Probably part of a two-piece set of moulds. Brown Nile silt with a thick grey core, common fine gold mica and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Probably from Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: Not an African as Walters has it, nor does he hold a pot (Walters 1903: E 54). No location given, but probably from Site 95 the terracottas workshop (Petrie 1886, 45).
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (E54)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DG.10) (Phase 3)
